Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposal focuses on the problem of topical link analysis with a goal to improve the relevance of web search results. A web page (or author) is not equally authoritative on all topics. However, traditional link analysis techniques consider only a single measure of authority, with little or no concern for the topic or community from which that authority is derived. This research finds ways to determine the context of recognized authority, and to incorporate that context as topicality or community recognition into more accurate automated analyses of reputation. This project further improves link analysis by distinguishing between popularity, quality, and authority. By integrating such analysis into fundamental link analysis techniques, search result quality improvements are demonstrated using human relevance and quality judgments. This contextual link analysis provides new opportunities to significantly improve measurements of authority and thus search engine result rankings (as well as topical rankings for other purposes), and to better understand the topical structure of interlinked document networks such as the Web and scholarly publications.

The project additionally incorporates educational and outreach activities, including a program to stimulate undergraduate interest and experience in computer science research in area schools, while promoting interaction among nearby faculty. The project web page
(http://www.cse.lehigh.edu/~brian/nsf/career-05.html) provides access to research results and additional information on project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A web page (or author) is not equally authoritative on all topics. However, traditional link analysis techniques considered only a single measure of authority or reputation, with little or no concern for the topic or community from which that authority is derived. As a result, a resource that is highly popular for one topic may dominate the results of another topic for which it is less authoritative.  We developed automatic mechanisms to determine the context of the recognized authority, and to incorporate that context as topicality or community recognition into more accurate analyses of reputation. 

By integrating such contextual link analyses into fundamental link analysis techniques, we were able to improve search result quality and demonstrated those improvements using human relevance and quality judgements.  We produced prototype implementations and applied these techniques both to web page ranking and to expert ranking (both in Q&A services and in citation networks).  

Our fundamental topical link analysis approach calculates a score vector for each object (e.g., web page, person, publication, venue, etc.) to distinguish the contribution from different topics.  We incorporated this model within both standard link analysis approaches PageRank and HITS.  We found that an extension of this model, which we named CommunityRank, to represent reputation per community, performed as well as, or better, than other topic-based extensions to PageRank. Finally, our Heterogeneous Topic Ranking approach, by maintaining topic authority flow, has provided even better performance, both on the Web and in citation networks. The additional information incorporated in multi-type citation networks provide better data on which to perform link analysis.

We were also able to make advances in understanding models of trust and how they can impact the effectiveness of spam.  Our cautious surfer approach was able to combine the spam demotion properties of TrustRank (or other trust estimation methods) with the authority calculations of PageRank so that good pages rank well and spam is demoted.  We found that propagation of trust does not need to be (and likely should not be) identical to propagation of authority. Non-trust preserving propagation is also valuable. It is often appropriate to propagate estimates of trust and distrust differently.

We demonstrated improved performance in question and answer detection in discussion boards through the incorporation of non-content features within a classification approach. We also showed that participant reputation models can be valuable in Q&A systems, and that the use of topical link analysis can often be beneficial.

Finally, we invented a novel, non-PageRank-based reputation estimation approach.  By decaying the contribution of ancestors depending on the number of generations away, we showed that an ancestor-based authority score can greatly improve upon a standard BM25 retrieval method and can be better than a PageRank-based retrieval.

This project helped result in thirty-five peer-reviewed publications, available from the project website.  More than a dozen invited talks described project results, including presentations at local universities and international venues. This project has contributed to the training and development of eight doctoral students and six master's degree students, who went on to Yahoo! Labs, Microsoft Bing, Google, and others after graduation.  We additionally had three visitors to the lab during the project period (one doctoral student and two faculty on sabbaticals).
